text.b: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis,

page.text: Louise Pacheco, Sequoia Union High School District
Christopher Dugan, TRA Environmental Sciences, Inc.
Subject: Carlmont High School Stadium Lighting Project Traffic Analysis
This memorandum presents the results of the traffic and parking analysis conducted for the Carlmont
High School Football Stadium Lighting Project. Carlmont High School (CHS) is located at 1400
Alameda De Las Pulgas, in the City of Belmont, California. The school is part of the Sequoia Union
High School District (SUHSD) and has a current enrollment of approximately 2,086 high school
students from the adjacent communities. The school is situated in a mixed residential and commercial
area. It is bounded on the north by Alameda de Las Pulgas, on the south by vegetated hillside open
space, on the east by single-family residences along Cranfield Drive, and on the west by multi-family
residences along Valerga Drive. The Tierra Linda Middle School (operated by the San Carlos School
District), Crossing Community Church, and single family residences are also located across Alameda
de Las Pulgas to the north. The Fale Hufanga Tongan United Methodist Church is located immediately
to the northeast of the CHS campus, with its driveway located just east of Cranfield Drive. Access to the
school’s main parking lot is provided via three existing driveways (see Figure 1). Two of the driveways
are located at the school’s eastern and western boundary, at El Verano Way and Cranfield Avenue,
respectively. These two driveways provide access to the school’s parking areas, located mainly along
the perimeter of the school site, and the student drop-off areas, located approximately 400 feet from the
driveway. The third driveway, located on Alameda de Las Pulgas at Chula Vista Drive, provides access
to a parking area located adjacent to Alameda de Las Pulgas and between the baseball fields and the
The SUHSD is proposing to install permanent field lights at Carlmont High School’s existing football
field, in addition to a permanent field public address (PA) system, and a new field bleacher seating
system. The football stadium is centrally located within the school campus. The field lighting, in
conjunction with the other proposed improvements, would be installed in anticipation of hosting night
time sporting events, such as high school football games, and other events such as soccer and
lacrosse games, varsity track and field meets, CHS graduation, community youth sports groups
practices and games, and/or athletic practices. According to information obtained from the SUHSD,
major sporting events would consist of approximately four to six junior varsity/varsity football games per
year, which would be held on Friday evenings, although they may be rescheduled to Thursday on rare
According to CHS staff, the existing attendance at varsity football games is typically an average of 700
attendants. However, attendance is normally highest against traditional “rival” schools, which in the
case of CHS is Sequoia High School. The last football game against Sequoia High School held at CHS

text.i: Appendix E: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis, February 2012
Appendix E: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis, February 2012

page.text: took place on November 10, 2011 and was attended by approximately 1,300 spectators. Carlmont High
School used temporary field lights and field PA system for this game.
The purpose of this memorandum is to analyze the impacts of the anticipated events occurring as a
direct result of the stadium lighting, in the context of the transportation system.
Carlmont High School is located within the City of Belmont, in San Mateo County. Based on the
City/County Association of Governments (C/CAG, the Congestion Management Agency for San Mateo
County) CMP guidelines, a project’s impacts should be analyzed during the weekday AM and PM peak
periods if it would add more than 100 peak hour trips to the CMP roadway system. CMP facilities within
the study area include US 101 and I-280. Implicit in this methodology is the assumption that the project
traffic generation would be sustained over the course of a typical week. However, in the case of special
events, there is no defined methodology for evaluating project specific impacts. Generally, it is not
considered economical to design transportation infrastructure for the busiest hour of the year.
According to the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO)
publication A Policy on Geometric Design of Highways and Streets 2001, a “reasonable” design
busiest hour of the year (Page 59). Thus, unless the proposed lighting
project would contain at least 30 major peak hour events per year, it would not be “reasonable” to
design transportation infrastructure to support the project. According to information obtained from CHS
staff, the proposed stadium lights would be used for approximately four to six varsity football games per
year. Thus, the typical standards for roadway design and level of service are not applicable to the
However, the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) stresses that the potential impacts of a
project must be disclosed to the public. While it appears that street widening or lane additions may not
be justified based on the traffic generation from the proposed project, in the spirit of CEQA, it was
determined by the project traffic consultant (Hexagon Transportation Consultants, Inc) that the
disclosure of “worst-case” traffic conditions created by the proposed lighting project would be
The traffic analysis of a project is based on the associated change in traffic from existing conditions to
the expected conditions with the project. As mentioned previously, the field lighting would be installed in
anticipation of hosting night time sporting events, such as high school football games, and other
sporting and non-sporting events. However, according to information obtained from the SUHSD, only
football games would be scheduled to occur at a different time than their current schedule once the field
lights are installed. All other events currently taking place at the school stadium would follow current
With the proposed stadium lights in place, the home football games would be scheduled to occur at a
later time than currently scheduled, with the main event (varsity football game) taking place from 7:00 to
10:30 PM on Fridays. It is expected that evening football games would generate more traffic during the
PM peak hour than the current day games. Therefore, in order to disclose the “worst-case” traffic
conditions created by the proposed lighting project, nearby intersections were evaluated for level of
service (LOS) with and without traffic from a proposed maximum capacity event (a varsity football
game) on a typical Friday PM peak period.
Though the field lights would be available for use by other non-football events, unlike football games,
scheduling of other games/activities currently taking place at the school stadium during the week would
not change. For non-football events, the intent of the field lights is to enable non-football games, such
as soccer games which are currently stopped before the end of the game due to lack of lighting, to run
for the entire length of the game with the proposed field lights in place. It is expected that traffic
generated by non-football events would be the same without or with the stadium lights.
Any potential new, non-football event traffic generated as a result of the stadium lights would be that
associated with people accessing the stadium solely because of the lights (i.e. neighbors accessing the
field to exercise at night.) However, it is expected that the potential “new” weekday PM peak hour

text.i: Appendix E: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis, February 2012

page.text: project trips would be insignificant, in particular when compared to the traffic that would be generated
by a sold-out football event, and would not cause any of the study intersections to deteriorate to
unacceptable levels. Therefore, an analysis of the weekday PM peak hour of traffic (an hour between
4:00 and 6:00 PM) was deemed unnecessary since the analysis of the Friday PM peak hour (with a
sold-out football game) would represent the worst-case scenario.
The following intersections were selected for evaluation:
1. Alameda De Las Pulgas and Ralston Avenue
2. Alameda De Las Pulgas and Carlmont Drive (unsignalized)
3. Alameda De Las Pulgas and El Verano Way (unsignalized)
4. Alameda De Las Pulgas and Chula Vista Drive (unsignalized)
5. Alameda De Las Pulgas/San Carlos Avenue and Cranfield Avenue (unsignalized)
6. Dartmouth Avenue/Club Drive and San Carlos Avenue (City of San Carlos)
Five of the study intersections (four of which are unsignalized intersections) are located within the City
of Belmont. The intersection of Dartmouth Avenue/Club Drive and San Carlos Avenue is located in the
City of San Carlos (see Figure 2). The intersections were analyzed during the Friday PM peak period
that coincides with the “pre-game peak hour” (6:00 to 7:00 PM). The operations of the key intersections
were evaluated for the following conditions:
Existing conditions were represented by existing Friday peak-
hour traffic volumes on the existing roadway network. Existing traffic volumes were
to as Project Conditions) were estimated by adding to the existing Friday traffic
volumes the additional traffic generated by the project. Project conditions were
evaluated relative to existing conditions in order to determine potential project
As the Congestion Management Agency (CMA) for San Mateo County, C/CAG is responsible for
maintaining the performance and standards of the Congestion Management Program (CMP) roadway
network. The CMP requires new development projected to add 100 or more peak hour trips to the CMP
roadway network to implement Travel Demand Management (TDM) measures that would reduce
project impacts. US 101 and I-280 are the only two CMP facilities in the vicinity of the project area. The
proposed project would not add more than 100 peak hour trips to either of these CMP facilities.
Therefore, an analysis based on the requirements of C/CAG is not necessary.

i.b: Analysis Methodologies and Level of Service Standards

page.text: Traffic conditions at the study intersections were evaluated using level of service (LOS). Level of
is a qualitative measure of traffic operations, ranging from LOS A (free-flow conditions with little
or no delay) to LOS F (forced-flow conditions with excessive delays). The various analysis methods are

text.i: Appendix E: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis, February 2012

text.b: School Location and Surrounding Transportation Network

text.i: Appendix E: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis, February 2012

page.text: According to the City/County Association of Governments (C/CAG) of San Mateo County 2009
Congestion Management Program (CMP) report, intersection levels of service are to be measured by
methods described in one of the following documents: The Transportation Research Board’s Circular
, the latest version of the Highway Capacity Manual (HCM), or a uniform methodology adopted by
the CMA that is consistent with the HCM.
Five out of the six study intersections are located within the City of Belmont (one is located within the
City of San Carlos). According to City of Belmont staff, the City does not have an adopted level of
service policy. Since the City of Belmont does not have an adopted level of service standard, these
intersections were analyzed based on City of San Carlos level of service standards and impact criteria.
The City of San Carlos adopted methodology for level of service analysis is the Critical Movement
Analysis methodology (Circular 212). This is one of the methodologies recommended by C/CAG and it
bases the evaluation of intersection operations on the turning movements that determine signal phasing
and greentime (the “critical movements”). Thus, this method provides a good indication of the ability of
an intersection to accommodate additional traffic. Capacities were adjusted to a maximum of 1800
vehicles per hour for a two-phase signal. The level of service is based on the volume to capacity ratio
Based on the City of San Carlos level of service standard, the acceptable level of service for the study
intersections is mid-level LOS D (V/C = 0.85) or better.
The unsignalized study intersections are located in the City of Belmont. The unsignalized study
intersections were analyzed using TRAFFIX software, which is based on the Highway Capacity Manual
(HCM) 2000 method for unsignalized intersections. For two-way stop-controlled intersections, the HCM
methodology separately evaluates opposing movements and assigns a level of service based on the
average total delays of traffic on the minor approach waiting for a gap in opposing traffic flow. The two-
way stop-controlled intersection level of service is not for the intersection as a whole, but rather, it
describes the worst movement of the intersection, typically left-turning traffic from the minor street
(controlled movement) onto the major street (uncontrolled movement.) For all-way stop-controlled
intersections, the control delay is calculated as the average of the entire intersection (average delay of
all controlled movements.) The average control delay can then be correlated to a level of service as
for unsignalized intersections. The City of Belmont has not adopted an intersection
The level of service analysis at unsignalized intersections is supplemented with an assessment of the
need for signalization of the intersection. The need for signalization of unsignalized intersections is
assessed based on the Peak Hour Volume Warrant (Warrant 3) described in the California Manual on

text.i: Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways (CA MUTCD)

page.text: Signals, 2010. This method makes no evaluation of intersection level of service, but simply provides an
indication whether vehicular peak hour traffic volumes are, or would be, sufficient to justify installation of
a traffic signal. Intersections that meet the peak hour warrant are subject to further analysis before
determining that a traffic signal is necessary. Additional analysis may include unsignalized level of
service analysis and/or operational analysis such as evaluating vehicle queuing and delay. Other
options such as traffic control devices, signage, or geometric changes may be preferable based on
existing field conditions. Additionally, engineering judgment is exercised on a case-by-case basis to
evaluate the effect a traffic signal will have on certain types of accidents and traffic conditions at the
subject intersection as well as at adjacent intersections.

text.i: Appendix E: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis, February 2012

text.b: Intersection Level of Service Definitions Based on Volume-to-Capacity Ratio

page.text: Uncongested operations; all queues clear in a single signal cycle.
Very light congestion; an occasional approach phase is fully utilized.
Light congestion; occasional backups on critical approaches.
Significant congestion on critical approaches, but intersection
functional. Cars required to wait through more than one cycle during
short peaks. No long-standing queues formed.
Severe congestion with some long-standing queues on critical
approaches. Blockage of intersection may occur if traffic signal
does not provide for protected turning movements. Traffic queue may
block nearby intersection(s) upstream of critical approach(es).
Uncongested operations; all queues clear in a single signal cycle.
Very light congestion; an occasional approach phase is fully utilized.
Light congestion; occasional backups on critical approaches.
Significant congestion on critical approaches, but intersection
functional. Cars required to wait through more than one cycle during
short peaks. No long-standing queues formed.
Severe congestion with some long-standing queues on critical
approaches. Blockage of intersection may occur if traffic signal
does not provide for protected turning movements. Traffic queue may
block nearby intersection(s) upstream of critical approach(es).

text.b: Level of Service Definitions for Unsignalized Intersections

page.text: Operations with low delays occurring with good progression.
Operations with average delays resulting from fair progression.
Operation with longer delays due to a combination of unfavorable progression
Operation with high delay values indicating poor progression and high V/C
ratios. This is considered to be the limited of acceptable delay.
Operation with delays unacceptable to most drivers occurring due to
Transportation Research Board, 2000 Highway Capacity Manual. (Washington, D.C., 2000)
Operations with very low delays occurring with favorable progression.
Operations with low delays occurring with good progression.
Operations with average delays resulting from fair progression.
Operation with longer delays due to a combination of unfavorable progression
Operation with high delay values indicating poor progression and high V/C
ratios. This is considered to be the limited of acceptable delay.
Operation with delays unacceptable to most drivers occurring due to
Transportation Research Board, 2000 Highway Capacity Manual. (Washington, D.C., 2000)
Operations with very low delays occurring with favorable progression.

text.i: Appendix E: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis, February 2012

page.text: The operations analysis is based on vehicle queuing for high-demand movements at intersections.
Vehicle queues were estimated using a Poisson probability distribution, which estimates the probability
of “n” vehicles for a vehicle movement using the following formula:
P (x=n) = probability of “n” vehicles in queue per lane
n = number of vehicles in the queue per lane
λ = average number of vehicles in the queue per lane (vehicles per hour per lane/signal cycles
The basis of the analysis is as follows: (1) the Poisson probability distribution is used to estimate the
percentile maximum number of queued vehicles per signal cycle for a particular movement; (2) the
estimated maximum number of vehicles in the queue is translated into a queue length, assuming 25
feet per vehicle; and (3) the estimated maximum queue length is compared to the existing or planned
available storage capacity for the movement.

text.i: Appendix E: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis, February 2012

page.text: This section describes the existing conditions for all of the major transportation facilities in the vicinity of
the Carlmont High School campus, including the roadway network, transit service, and bicycle and
Carlmont High School is located at 1400 Alameda de Las Pulgas, in the City of Belmont. Regional
vehicle access to the project site is provided via Alameda de Las Pulgas and Ralston Avenue (see
Figure 1). Direct access to the project site is provided via Alameda de Las Pulgas. These facilities are
is mainly a northwest roadway that extends from Santa Cruz Avenue
in Menlo Park northward to San Mateo where it terminates at a T-intersection with Crystal
Springs Road. At its intersection with San Carlos Avenue, in San Carlos, Alameda de Las
Pulgas changes designation to San Carlos Avenue, and it changes back to Alameda de Las
Pulgas at Cranfield Avenue, in Belmont. Alameda de Las Pulgas transverses the Cities of
Menlo Park, Redwood City, San Carlos, Belmont, and San Mateo. It is mainly a two-lane
roadway with the exception of most of the segment within the City of San Mateo, which is a
four-lane segment. Alameda de Las Pulgas is also CHS's northern boundary, and it provides
direct access to the school's parking areas via driveways at El Verano Way, Chula Vista Drive,
and a driveway parallel to Cranfield Avenue. It should be noted that although the driveway
providing access to the school is not on Cranfield Avenue but next to it (west of it), for
simplicity, this driveway is referred to as the Cranfield driveway within this report. A second
driveway also is located parallel to the school driveway and Cranfield Avenue, east of Cranfield
Avenue. This second driveway provides access to the Fale Hufanga Tongan United Methodist
Church, located immediately to the northeast of the CHS campus.
is mainly a four-lane arterial that extends from SR 92 to US 101. West of SR
92, it becomes Polhemus Road while east of US 101 it becomes Marine Parkway. Ralston
Avenue provides access to the project site via its intersection with Alameda de Las Pulgas.
Existing pedestrian access to the school site entrances on Alameda de Las Pulgas is provided by
sidewalks on Alameda de Las Pulgas and adjacent residential streets. Sidewalks are found along one
or both sides of most residential streets in the vicinity of the school, with crosswalks provided at all
intersections on Alameda de Las Pulgas in the vicinity of the school. However, sidewalks are missing
along the north side of Alameda de Las Pulgas, between Chula Vista Drive and Cranfield Avenue,
along both sides on Cranfield Avenue, and along one or both sides of San Carlos Avenue, between
Bike lanes are provided along the following roadway segments in the vicinity of the project site:
Alameda de Las Pulgas, between Carlmont Drive and Cranfield Avenue, and between San
San Carlos Avenue, between Beverly Drive and Elm Street
Ralston Avenue, between S Road (west of El Camino Real) and Alameda de Las Pulgas
According to CHS staff, the high school currently has 361 parking spaces on-site, including staff,
student, handicapped, and visitor parking spaces. The parking spaces are provided within two parking
areas: the first parking area located along the perimeter of the school (not including Alameda de Las
Pulgas) and accessed via the driveways at El Verano Way and Cranfield Avenue, consists of
approximately 236 parking spaces, while the second parking area, located along Alameda de Las

text.i: Appendix E: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis, February 2012

page.text: Pulgas and accessed via the driveway at Chula Vista Drive, consists of approximately 125 parking
Additionally, approximately 38 parking spaces are provided along the school frontage on Alameda de
Las Pulgas, between Chula Vista Drive and Cranfield Avenue. These parking spaces are undesignated
Existing transit service in the vicinity of the school site is provided by the San Mateo County Transit
District (SamTrans). The closest bus stops are located at the intersections of Alameda de Las Pulgas
and El Verano Way and Dartmouth Avenue/Club Drive and San Carlos Avenue. SamTrans provides
bus service along the following two routes:
Route 260 provides service between the San Carlos Caltrain Station and the College of San Mateo,
Carlmont Village Shopping Center, Downtown Belmont, Notre Dame de Namur University,
Redwood Shores, and Chula Vista and Fernwood
. The Chula Vista and Fernwood route is only served
on weekdays for a limited time period in the morning and afternoon, to coincide with the beginning
and end of the school day at CHS.
Route 295 provides service between the Menlo Park and San Mateo Caltrain stations on 30 to 60-
minute headways via Alameda de Las Pulgas in the vicinity of the project site. Route 295 also
serves the Redwood City, San Carlos and Hillsdale Caltrain stations.
The existing lane configurations and signal timing and phasing (for the signalized intersections) were
determined by observations in the field. Existing traffic volumes at the study intersections were obtained
from new intersection turning movement counts (conducted in November, 2011). The existing
intersection lane configurations and intersection turning movement volumes are shown graphically on
The results of the level of service are summarized in Table 3. The operations of the study intersections
were evaluated, using TRAFFIX software, for the Friday peak hour that coincides with the evening
football event peak hour (6:00-7:00 PM.) The results show that the study signalized intersections
currently operate at an acceptable LOS A during the Friday peak hour.
The results also show that all of the unsignalized study intersections currently operate at LOS C or
better during the Friday peak hour. The level of service calculation sheets are shown in the attached
The results of the peak-hour traffic signal warrant checks are summarized on Table 4. The results
indicate that none of the unsignalized study intersections currently have peak-hour volumes that satisfy
the peak-hour traffic signal warrant during the Friday peak-hour (6:00-7:00 PM.) The peak-hour signal
warrant sheets are contained in the appendix.

text.i: Appendix E: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis, February 2012

text.i: Appendix E: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis, February 2012

page.text: This section analyzes traffic conditions on the surrounding transportation network after completion of
the proposed project. Included are descriptions of the significance criteria that define an impact,
estimates of project-generated traffic, and identification of project impacts. Project conditions are
represented by existing traffic with the addition of traffic generated by the project.
The Sequoia Union High School District (SUHSD) is proposing to install stadium lighting at Carlmont
High School’s (CHS) existing athletic field. The football stadium is centrally located within the school
campus. The field lighting, in conjunction with the other proposed improvements, would be installed in
anticipation of hosting night time sporting events, such as high school football games, and soccer and
lacrosse games, in addition to varsity track and field meets, CHS graduation, community youth sports
groups practices and games, and/or athletic practices. According to information obtained from the
SUHSD (based on the current 2011 sporting events schedule for CHS), major sporting events would
consist of approximately four to six junior varsity/varsity football games per year, which would be held
on Friday evenings, although they may be rescheduled to Thursday on rare occasions. Additionally,
there would be approximately 12 soccer games, 8 lacrosse games, and 4 track meets per year, in
addition to ongoing sport practices, community youth sports, and special events held at the football field
after installation of the proposed stadium lights. Football games would take place on Fridays from 4:00
PM to 10:30 PM (Jr. varsity football games would be from 4:00 PM to 6:00 PM and varsity football
games would be from 7:00 PM to 10:30 PM). Soccer and lacrosse games and sport practices would
take place Monday through Friday, with these events ending by 9:00 PM.
With the proposed stadium lights in place, the home football games would be scheduled to occur at a
later time than currently scheduled, with the main event (varsity football game) taking place from 7:00 to
10:30 PM on Fridays. Even though the field lights also would be available for use by other non-football
events, unlike football games, scheduling of other games/activities currently taking place at the school
stadium during the week would not change. For non-football events, the intent of the field lights is to
enable non-football games, such as soccer games which are currently stopped before the end of the
game due to lack of lighting, to run for the entire length of the game with the proposed field lights in
place. It is expected that traffic generated by non-football events during the week would be the same
without or with the stadium lights.
According to CHS staff, the existing attendance at varsity football games is typically an average of 700
spectators. However, attendance is normally highest against traditional “rival” schools, which in the
case of CHS is Sequoia High School. CHS’s inaugural evening game in 2009, which was against
Sequoia High School, drew approximately 1,800 spectators. Two evening games held in 2010 against
non-rival opponents drew 800 and 500 spectators. The last football game against Sequoia High School
held at CHS took place on November 10, 2011 and was attended by approximately 1,300 spectators.
Carlmont High School used temporary field lights and field public address system for this game. Other
sporting non-football events taking place at the school stadium during the week, such as soccer and
lacrosse, are typically attended by a relatively smaller audience (approximately 50 spectators,
In addition to the installation of the stadium lighting, the SUHSD is proposing to install a permanent field
public address (PA) system, and a new field bleacher seating system. The football stadium currently
provides bleacher seats for approximately 600 spectators. The proposed new bleachers would be
located on the north side of the football field, parallel to existing tennis courts, and they would be
designated as the visitor seating area. The new bleachers would have a seating capacity of 456. With
new visitor bleachers plus the existing (home) bleachers, the football stadium would have a total
The amount of traffic generated by the proposed project was estimated by applying trip generation rates
to the size of the project (the maximum number of spectators the CHS football stadium could attract as
a result of the installation of the proposed stadium lights). The trip rates used for this analysis were

text.i: Appendix E: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis, February 2012

page.text: obtained from other similar high school stadium lighting projects in the Bay Area. These high school
stadium trip generation rates were developed by Fehr and Peers Associates and are based on surveys
of high school football events at schools with stadium lighting (Santa Teresa High School Football

text.i: Stadium Lighting Traffic and Parking Analysis

page.text: generation estimates are presented in Table 5.
2. Assumes maximum capacity at a varsity football game on a Friday night.
1. Rates expressed in trips per attendee. The trip rates were developed by Fehr and Peers Associates
based on a survey conducted at Santa Teresa High School, in San Jose, California, and documented
in Santa Teresa High School Football Stadium Lighting Traffic and Parking Analysis , Memorandum,
2. Assumes maximum capacity at a varsity football game on a Friday night.
1. Rates expressed in trips per attendee. The trip rates were developed by Fehr and Peers Associates
based on a survey conducted at Santa Teresa High School, in San Jose, California, and documented
in Santa Teresa High School Football Stadium Lighting Traffic and Parking Analysis , Memorandum,
The project trip generation was estimated for a sold-out varsity football event. Although the typical
attendance at varsity football games at CHS ranges from 500-1,800 spectators, Hexagon determined
that the analysis of the project should not be conducted based on the highest attendance (1,800
spectators) since that was the very first evening game (with the use of temporary field lights) held at
CHS against a rival school, and as such attendance is believed to be higher than what it would
“normally” be after installation of the field lights. This in fact is reflected in the attendance to the last
night game held at CHS against Sequoia High School. Thus, the analysis of the project was conducted
based on the average of the two largest attendance evening games (1,800 and 1,300 spectators),
approximately 1,550 spectators. A night game generating 1,550 spectators would represent a sold-out
game. Although the stadium’s seating capacity would be less than the number of spectators estimated
for a sold-out game, it was assumed that some spectators would be standing, as it was observed at the
The surveyed trip generation rates associated with the varsity football game and used for the analysis
of the project include trips associated with a preceding junior varsity football game. This is reflected in
the directional split of pre-varsity game traffic (in and outs)Thus, the estimated outbound trips include
both spectators being dropped-off at the school site for the varsity football event as well as junior varsity
game attendees leaving the site by driving or being picked-up.
Based on the above information and assumptions, it was estimated that the stadium lighting project
would generate 868 trips (608 inbound and 260 outbound trips) during the Friday PM peak hour for a
It should be noted that capacity events would only occur a maximum of four to six times a year,
assuming all football games would sell out. Additionally, it was assumed that all traffic generated by a
sold-out football game, and non-football game event, would be new traffic on the roadway network. This
is not entirely true, since according to CHS staff, weekday football games take place during the day
staring at 3:00 PM (2:45 PM after daylight savings time) and finishing at around 6:00 PM, generating
traffic associated with the football event during the Friday PM peak hour. This traffic is project related
traffic already on the roadway network. Nevertheless, this study included scenarios with total project
traffic added to peak hour traffic in the interests of disclosing the potential “worst case” scenarios.

text.i: Appendix E: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis, February 2012

page.text: Based on information obtained from CHS regarding the school’s attendance area, field observations at
the existing site, and existing turn-movement counts, the origins of vehicle traffic at CHS were
23% from Ralston Avenue, east of Alameda de Las Pulgas
15% from Ralston Avenue, west of Alameda de Las Pulgas
15% from Alameda de Las Pulgas, north of Ralston Avenue
The trips generated by the proposed project were then assigned to the roadway network based on this
directional distribution. Figure 4 shows the proposed project’s trip distribution and assignment.
Although the City of Belmont does not have adopted impact criteria for intersection analysis, based on
City of San Carlos level of service impact criteria, the project is said to create a significant adverse
impact on traffic conditions at a signalized intersection if, for either peak hour, the level of service at the
intersection degrades from an acceptable mid-level LOS D (V/C = 0.85) or better under existing
conditions (or future conditions without the project) to an unacceptable high LOS D, LOS E or F under
future conditions with the project. If an intersection is found to operate at an unacceptable high-end
LOS D (V/C > 0.85) or worse under existing conditions (or future conditions without the project), the
intersection would be impacted by the project if the addition of the project trips would cause the V/C
ratio at the intersection to increase by 0.01 or more.
Neither the City of San Carlos nor the City of Belmont have adopted impact criteria for unsignalized
intersections. It is common for jurisdictions not to have an adopted impact criteria for unsignalized
intersections. Nevertheless, unsignalized intersection level of service analysis is sometimes performed
for informational purposes and to identify locations that might need improvements, such as the
installation of a traffic signal. When that is the case, deficiencies identified at unsignalized intersections
are typically not considered significant intersection impacts that must be identified and mitigated to
satisfy CEQA guidelines. Instead, they are identified as intersection operational deficiencies.
Intersection operational deficiencies are subject to the local jurisdiction’s procedures and standards.
Thus, the unsignalized intersection level of service analysis is provided for informational purposes only.
Additionally, the level of service analysis at the unsignalized intersections is supplemented with an
assessment of the need for signalization of the intersection. The need for signalization of unsignalized
intersections is assessed based on the Peak Hour Volume Warrant (Warrant 3) described in the

text.i: California Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways (CA MUTCD)

page.text: The project condition levels of service for the “worst-case” events are shown in Table 6. Under existing
plus project conditions, the level of service analysis show that the study signalized intersections would
continue to operate at an acceptable mid-level LOS D or better during the Friday PM peak hour.
Therefore, the proposed project would not have a negative impact at the study signalized intersections.

indicate that the traffic generated by a Friday sold-out game would cause the traffic signal warrant to be
met at three of the four study unsignalized intersections. The peak-hour signal warrant sheets are

As with the unsignalized intersection analysis, this information is provided for informational purposes
only. However, it should be noted that temporary measures to control traffic during the beginning and
end of a sold-out event, such as the use of police officers to direct traffic, could be implemented to help
improve operations at the unsignalized intersections providing access to the school. It is recommended
that the SUHSD works with the City of Belmont in an effort to improve operating conditions at these
intersections during sold-out events at the school’s stadium.
The analysis of project intersection level of service was supplemented with an analysis of intersection
operations for selected locations. The operations analysis is based on vehicle queuing for high-demand
movements at intersections. Vehicle queues were estimated using a Poisson probability distribution.
The basis of the analysis is as follows: (1) the Poisson probability distribution is used to estimate the
percentile maximum number of queued vehicles per signal cycle for a particular movement; (2) the
estimated maximum number of vehicles in the queue is translated into a queue length, assuming 25
feet per vehicle; and (3) the estimated maximum queue length is compared to the existing or planned
available storage capacity for the movement. This analysis thus provides a basis for estimating future
storage requirements at the selected locations. The queue estimates and a tabulated summary of the
findings for the weekday and Friday PM peak hours are provided in Table 8. The Poisson probability
calculation sheets are provided in the appendix.

text.i: Appendix E: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis, February 2012

page.text: Vehicle queue calculations based on cycle length for signalized intersections and control delay for unsignalized intersections.
Vehicle queue calculations based on cycle length for signalized intersections and control delay for unsignalized intersections.

text.i: Appendix E: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis, February 2012

page.text: It should be noted that deficiencies identified by the intersection operations analysis are typically not
considered significant intersections impacts but instead are identified as intersection operational
deficiencies. Intersection impacts, such as level of service impacts, must be identified and mitigated to
satisfy CEQA guidelines. Intersection operational deficiencies, however, are subject to the local
The operations analysis indicated that the estimated maximum vehicle queue for the westbound left
turn movement on Ralston Avenue to southbound Alameda De Las Pulgas would exceed the existing
vehicle storage capacity under existing plus project conditions during the Friday PM peak hour.
However, the same turn movement is shown to be deficient under existing conditions. The maximum
queue length for this movement is projected to be 11 vehicles (or 275 feet long) under existing
conditions. The existing storage capacity for this movement is approximately 200 feet. Under existing
plus project conditions, the project traffic would extend the vehicle queue length by as many as 6
vehicles (or from 275 to 425 feet) during the Friday PM peak hour. It is not possible to extend this left-
turn pocket due to the adjacent eastern intersection of Villa Avenue and Ralston Avenue.
Due to the additional traffic that would be generated during the PM peak hour as a result of the stadium
lighting, there will likely be periods of traffic congestion on the roadways before and after major events.
This would occur since event traffic demand is typically not spread evenly throughout the peak hour, but
it is not expected to last for long periods of time.
To help deal with these periods during a sold-out event, the following measures are recommended:
Traffic flaggers should be used at the school’s existing driveways and onsite to help patrons locate
To address the congestion at intersections providing direct access to the school, the SUHSD in
conjunction with the City of Belmont may wish to employ the use officers/flaggers at these
intersections to control and direct traffic as they enter and/or leave the school site.
According to CHS staff, the high school currently has 361 parking spaces on-site, including staff,
student, handicapped, and visitor parking spaces. The parking spaces are provided within two parking
areas: the first parking area located along the perimeter of the school (not including Alameda de Las
Pulgas) and accessed via the driveways at El Verano Way and Cranfield Avenue, consists of
approximately 236 parking spaces, while the second parking area, located along Alameda de Las
Pulgas and accessed via the driveway at Chula Vista Drive, consists of approximately 125 parking
spaces. Additionally, approximately 38 parking spaces are provided along the school frontage on
Alameda de Las Pulgas, between Chula Vista Drive and Cranfield Avenue. These parking spaces are
undesignated on-street parking spaces. All together, the total parking supply for the school is 399
Although not specific to high school stadiums, the City of Belmont Schedule of Parking Requirements
(Section 8.4 of the City of Belmont Zoning Ordinance) includes parking requirements for stadiums
(section 8.4.6 Community Service Uses). Parking requirements for this land use, described as
stadiums, arenas, auditoriums (other than college or school), convention halls, dance halls, exhibit
halls, skating rinks, and other similar places of assembly, require provision of parking spaces equal to
20 percent of capacity in persons. Applying the City of Belmont parking requirement to the estimated
number of spectators at a sold-out varsity football game (instead of the number of seats since it was
estimated that a sold-out varsity football game would generate more spectators than the future stadium
seating capacity), it was estimated that a sold-out varsity football game would have a parking demand
Since the rates specified in the City of Belmont’s parking requirements are not specific to high school
stadiums, additional research on the parking requirements for stadiums in various Bay Area cities was
done. Various cities' parking requirements list the required number of parking spaces for football
stadiums, ranging from a low of one parking space for each 5 seats (0.20 parking spaces per seat) to
one parking space for every 3 seats (0.33 parking spaces per seat), with an average of 0.27 parking
spaces per seat (see Table 9). Please note that in addition to the required number of spaces based on

page.text: the available number of seats, some jurisdictions also require additional parking for usable floor area
Using a conservative assumption of one parking space for every 3 spectators, a sold-out varsity football
game would require 517 parking spaces. Applying the calculated average of all the stadium parking
requirements available (0.27 parking spaces per seat), a total of 419 parking spaces would need to be
As a check, the parking demand also was estimated based on the trip generation estimates. It was
estimated that there would be 608 inbound peak hour trips generated by a sold-out varsity football
game. Out of the 608 trips, 260 would be dropping off (or picking up) spectators, and the remaining 348
(608-260=348) would be parking for the game. To this must be added cars already parked for the
Junior Varsity game, which would be estimated to be at least 100 cars.
Based on the parking demand estimates above, the parking supply at CHS (399 spaces including on-
street spaces) would not be sufficient to serve the projected parking demand during a sold-out football
game, which could potentially experience a parking shortage of up to 100 parking spaces.
Carlmont High School has previously worked with the neighboring churches to be able to use their
parking supply during high trip generating events at the high school. Additionally, the SUHSD is
considering construction of a new parking area, north of the football stadium and adjacent to the
existing tennis courts, that would provide an additional 50 to 75 parking spaces to serve the school. A
new parking area, in conjunction with off-site parking agreements and the existing on-site parking
supply, would result in adequate parking supply to serve the projected parking demand generated by a
Other parking management strategies that could be implemented to ensure that adequate parking
spaces will be available at the school site during a sold-out football game include:
The school should not schedule other events on campus during the same evening as a sold-out
A parking plan should be developed to fully utilize all available parking within the school parking
areas. This may require directing traffic flow in and out of the school parking areas and
directing drivers to available parking spaces.
Open space within the school campus could be used to provide temporary parking areas. This
could include parking on existing grass fields, basketball courts, or any other available open
The school might want to consider procuring an off-site parking agreement with one of the
adjacent schools and/or churches in the case additional parking is needed.
The school should advise football fans to carpool to the games.
The school should advise event patrons not to park in the adjacent neighborhood.

text.i: Appendix E: Carlmont High School Field Lighting Project Traffic Analysis, February 2012

page.text: The results of this analysis indicate that there generally would be adequate roadway capacity to
accommodate the proposed Carlmont High School stadium lighting project under worst-case traffic
The level of service analysis show that the study signalized intersections would continue to operate at
an acceptable mid-level LOS D or better during the Friday PM peak hour. Therefore, the proposed
project would not have a negative impact at the study signalized intersections.
The analysis of the unsignalized intersections show that three of the study unsignalized intersections
are projected to deteriorate to LOS E during the Friday PM peak hour.
The results of the peak-hour traffic signal warrant checks indicate that the traffic generated by a Friday
sold-out game would cause the traffic signal warrant to be met at three of the four study unsignalized
intersections, including the Alameda De Las Pulgas/Carlmont Drive intersection which was shown to
warrant a traffic signal under existing conditions.
Both the unsignalized intersection analysis and the signal warrant checks are provided for informational
purposes only. However, it should be noted that temporary measures to control traffic during the
beginning and end of a sold-out event, such as the use of police officers to direct traffic, could be
implemented to help improve operations at the unsignalized intersections providing access to the
school. It is recommended that the SUHSD works with the City of Belmont in an effort to improve
operating conditions at these intersections during sold-out events at the school’s stadium.
The operations analysis indicated that the estimated maximum vehicle queue for the westbound left
turn movement on Ralston Avenue to southbound Alameda De Las Pulgas would exceed the existing
vehicle storage capacity under existing plus project conditions during the Friday PM peak hour. The
existing storage capacity for this movement is approximately 200 feet. Under existing plus project
conditions, the project traffic would extend the vehicle queue length by as many as 6 vehicles (or from
275 to 425 feet) during the Friday PM peak hour. It is not possible to extend this left-turn pocket due to
the adjacent eastern intersection of Villa Avenue and Ralston Avenue.
Based on the parking demand estimates above, the parking supply at CHS (399 spaces including on-
street spaces) would not be sufficient to serve the projected parking demand during a sold-out football
game, which could potentially experience a parking shortage of up to 100 parking spaces.
Carlmont High School has previously worked with the neighboring churches to be able to use their
parking supply during high trip generating events at the high school. Additionally, the SUHSD is
considering construction of a new parking area, north of the football stadium and adjacent to the
existing tennis courts, that would provide an additional 50 to 75 parking spaces to serve the school. A
new parking area, in conjunction with off-site parking agreements and the existing on-site parking
supply, would result in adequate parking supply to serve the projected parking demand generated by a
Other parking management strategies that could be implemented to ensure that adequate parking
spaces will be available at the school site during a sold-out football game include:
To address the congestion at intersections providing direct access to the school, the SUHSD in
conjunction with the City of Belmont may wish to employ the use officers/flaggers at these
intersections to control and direct traffic as they enter and/or leave the school site.
The school should not schedule other events on campus during the same evening as a sold-out
A parking plan should be developed to fully utilize all available parking within the school parking
areas. This may require directing traffic flow in and out of the school parking areas and
directing drivers to available parking spaces.
Open space within the school campus could be used to provide temporary parking areas. This
could include parking on existing grass fields, basketball courts, or any other available open

page.text: The school might want to consider procuring an off-site parking agreement with one of the
adjacent schools and/or churches in the case additional parking is needed.
The school should advise football fans to carpool to the games.
The school should advise event patrons not to park in the adjacent neighborhood.
This concludes Hexagon’s analysis of the proposed Carlmont High School stadium lighting project. If
you have any questions, please do not hesitate to call.
